results.title: Cree way
results.creator_credit: Tony Ianzelo, Mark Zannis and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: John Murdock, principal of the Indian Affairs at Rupert House, James Bay, and his wife Gerti, have initiated a curriculum development project using local people and resources. The teaching materials are drawn from Cree folklore, are mainly in Cree, and make use of old photographs, artifacts and books that are written and printed in the community. The school year is organised so that pupils have time to go hunting and fishing with their families. This innovative approach makes local control of education a reality in native communities.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Ianzelo, Mark Zannis and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Cree hunters of Mistassini
results.creator_credit: Boyce Richardson, Tony Ianzelo, Colin Low and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: During the winters, since times pre-dating agriculture, the Cree Indian people of Mistassini have gone to the bush of the James and Ungava Bay area to hunt. Three hunting families agreed to meet an NFBC crew, who filmed the building of the winter camp, the hunting , the relationship to the land, the rhythms of Cree family life. This sensitive film expresses Cree beliefs and ecological principles that are the foundation of their lives. (Awards include: Melbourne, Toronto, London)

results.title: Creating with watercolor
results.creator_credit: David Hubbard, Dick Hoffman, Tom Hubbard and Crystal Productions
results.brief_description: Watercolour artist, Cecile Johnson, is seen painting several landscapes as she talks about colour selection, paper texture and watercolour in general.

results.title: Crossing borders
results.creator_credit: Barbara Laing, Jeanne Kracher, Linda Balek and Film Project for Women's History and Future
results.brief_description: The story of the Women’s International League for Peace and Freedom, the longest standing organisation of its kind. Begun during the first World War and still alive all around the world, the WILPF is a testament to women’s historic resistance to militarism and oppression. Despite their important place in history, the WILPF’s study has, until now, remained buried. “Crossing Borders” uncovers this dramatic and forgotten chapter in history.

results.title: Crosses
results.brief_description: A documentary that examines the experiences of Australian soldiers fighting in the Middle East and at Gallipoli during World War 1, between 1914-1918. Archival film footage shows the conditions on the battlefields, and ex-soldiers recount their experiences.

results.title: Creating a homely atmosphere
results.creator_credit: Tim Abbott, Helen Edwards, Tony Shaddock and Dept of Health, Richmond Implementation Unit
results.brief_description: Designed to introduce the intellectual disability residential care worker to some simple ways of creating a homelike environment in the physical sense with furnishing and decor, how to create a desirable psychological atmosphere through community involvement and high quality staff-resident, staff-staff and resident-resident interactions, an interpretation of the term “normalisation” and how this principle might be applied in a residential setting and the recognition of the individual resident’s rights in what is their home. Accompanied by 32p. in-service training manual.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tim Abbott, Helen Edwards, Tony Shaddock and Dept of Health, Richmond Implementation Unit

results.title: Cross and passion
results.creator_credit: Claire Pollak, Kim Longinotto and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: The women of Northern Ireland tell their stories in this film shot in the troubled Catholic ghetto area of West Belfast. Shows how life for Women in Belfast’s ghettos is dominated by the contrasting power of the church and army.

results.title: Crocodile Dundee II. (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: John Cornell, Jane Scott and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Begins in New York where Dundee now lives with his journalist girlfriend. In order to escape the pursuit of an international drug ring who have murdered her former husband, Dundee and his girlfriend return to the Australian outback where Dundee is well prepared to confront them.
